it's about freedom. we can second guess anyone. that

and i'm free to ban you for giving new users bad advice.
freedom goes both ways.
i don;t understand how running public services necessitates a firewall
it's a good security practise.
i don't see how running public services changes anything, though
there's more risk when you run a webserver, ftp server etc.
how does a firewall help that, though?
because a firewall will block traffic that is unwanted.
a firewall restricts access to ports. running a public service by definition means you want ports open. so a firewall is useful to a public facing server only for the ports it closes.
unless you get into IP or netblock restrictions, which has to be automated to scale well
yes. exactly. would you recommend running a webserver without a firewall?
i do.
what would a firewall give me? the abilit to ... block access to a server i set up so people can access it
block access to ports that you don't want people trying to exploit
if there are no services answering on those ports, a firewall is pointless.
then why do they exist?
there are god reasons to run a firewall. but simply having a public facing server doesn't translate into a need for a firewall.
ok. I'm listening.
for instance, to specifically redirect traffic across ports.
or allow access only from certain IPs or netblocks
